item.title: Report E-2024050021
item.description:
Report E-2024050021

Identified by scraper @ 2024-05-06T15:11:32+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-04-23
  • City: BIRMINGHAM
  • State: AL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On April 23, 2024, one (1) 55-gallon drum of paint was punctured by a forklift and released approximately twenty (20) gallons of paint to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Marion Environmental (ME) to remediate the impacted site. ME personnel utilized hand tools and absorbents to remediate the paint-impacted trailer floor. The damaged drum was overpacked into one (1) 95-gallon overpack and all impacted absorbents and waste were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum. Both were staged on site for transport and disposal.

item.title: Report E-2024040178
item.description:
Report E-2024040178

Identified by scraper @ 2024-05-06T15:11:32+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-04-03
  • City: MONTGOMERY
  • State: AL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: CSX Transportation
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 1500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 4/3/2024, at 16:54 hours, personnel in the CSXT Montgomery, AL Yard discovered TJRX 30025, a residue tank car that last contained Petroleum Distillates, NOS leaking from the bottom of the car. The car was isolated and the shipper, Gardner Asphalt, was notified via CHEMTREC (report 1395529). Marion Environmental, Inc. (MEI), a CSXT emergency response contractor, was dispatched to the scene and product leaking from the bottom outlet valve (BOV) with the valve in the closed position. MEI personnel actuated the valve between closed and open positions multiple times; once the valve was fully reclosed the release stopped. Upon further inspection, it was noted that the gasket in the bottom outlet valve cap was worn. Additionally, pieced of debris and corrosion were observed in the cap. It is suspected that corrosion and debris present in the valve seat were the cause for product flow through the valve in the closed position. Response personnel installed a new BOV cap gasket and secured the car for transportation. The issue identified and corrective actions were communicated to the shipperâ€™s representative (Duane Thomas, 443-875-4818).
